dialogues.text: The story is ludicrous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mein nommen iss Karl.  Is hard to  verk in zese clozes-- Maude switches off the set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord.  You can imagine where it goes  from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fixes the cable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be fatuous, Jeffrey.  Little  matter to me that this woman chose  to pursue a career in pornography, nor that she has been "banging" Jackie  Treehorn, to use the parlance of our times.  However.  I one of two trustees of the Lebowski Foundation, the other being my father.  The Foundation takes youngsters from Wa and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit yeah, the achievers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Lebowski Urban Achievers,  yes, and proud we are of all of them.   I asked my father about his withdrawal  of a million dollars from the  Foundation account and he told me  about this "abduction", but I tell  you it is preposterous.  This  compulsive fornicator is taking my father for the proverbial ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but my-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting to your rug. My  father  and I don't get along; he doesn't  approve of my lifestyle and, needless  to say, I don't approve of his.   Still, I hardly wish to make my  father's embezzlement a police matter,  so I'm proposing that you try to  recover the money from the people  you delivered it to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--sure, I could do that--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you successfully do so, I will  compensate you to the tune of 1% of  the recovered sum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thousand, yes, bones or clams or  whatever you call them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but what about--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --your rug, yes, well with that money  you can buy any number of rugs that  don't have sentimental value for me.   And I am sorry about that crack on  the jaw. The Dude fingers his jaw, where the lump from the sap has all but disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh that's okay, I hardly even--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the name and number of a doctor  who will look at it for you.  You  will receive no bill.  He's a good  man, and thorough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's really thoughtful but I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please see him, Jeffrey.  He's a  good man, and thorough.

dialogues.speaker: LIMO
dialogues.text: The Dude sits in back holding a White Russian,  listening the chauffeur, a man of about the same age from whose liv cap a ponytail emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --So he says, "My son can't hold a  job, my daughter's married to a  fuckin' loser, and I got a rash on  my ass so bad I can't hardly siddown.   But you know me.  I can't complain."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' A, man.  I got a rash.                          Fuckin' A, man.  I gotta tell ya  Tony. He takes a sip of a freshly-mixed White Russian, which le milk on his mustache. I was feeling really shitty earlier in the day, I'd lost little  money, I  was down in the dumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, forget about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, man!  Fuck it!  I can't be  worrying about that shit.  Life goes  on! The limo has rolled to a stop.  The Dude gets out, still  holding his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home sweet home, Mr. L.  Who's your  friend in the Volkswagon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? His eyes on the rearview mirror, Tony jerks a thumb over shoulder. He followed us here. The Dude turns to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halfway up the block a Volkswagon bug has pulled over to curb.  In the driver's seat we see a fat man's shape.

dialogues.speaker: THE DUDE
dialogues.text: He scowls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did he- The Dude is grabbed from behind and muscled away in a hal nelson by another uniformed chauffeur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into the limo, you sonofabitch.  No  arguments. As he is frog-marched towards another limo the Dude holds his drink away from his chest and cups a hand underneath

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck, man!  There's a beverage here! The waiting limo's back door is flung open.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: The Dude is shoved in and awkwardly takes a seat facing t rear. The door is slammed behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start talking and talk fast you lousy  bum!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been frantically trying to  reach you, Dude. Brandt sits catty-corner from the Dude; directly across f the Dude is the big Lebowski, a comforter across his knee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my goddamn money, you bum?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we--I don't--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They did not receive the money, you  nitwit!  They  did not receive the  goddamn money.  HER LIFE WAS IN YOUR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our concern, Dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, man, nothing is fucked here--

dialogues.speaker: HAS CRASHED INTO THE MOUNTAIN
dialogues.text: The Dude takes a hurried sip from his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon man, who're you gonna believe?   Those guys are--we dropped off the  damn money--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I--the royal we, you know, the  editorial--I dropped off the money,  exactly as per--Look, I've got certain  information, certain things have  come to light, and uh, has it ever  occurred to you, man, that given the  nature of all this new shit, that,  uh, instead of running around blaming  me, that this whole thing might just  be, not, you know, not just such a  simple, but uh--you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in God's holy name are you  blathering about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what I'm blathering  about!  I got information--new shit  has come to light and--shit, man!   She kidnapped herself! Lebowski stares at him, dumbstruck.  The Dude is encourag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well sure, look at it!  Young trophy  wife, I mean, in the parlance of our  times, owes money all over town,  including to known pornographers-- and that's cool, that's cool-- but  I'm saying, she needs money, and of  course they're gonna say they didn't  get it 'cause she wants more, man,  she's gotta feed the monkey, I mean-- hasn't that ever occurred to you...?   Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No Mr. Lebowski, that had not  occurred to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That had not occurred to us, Dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, okay, you're not privy to all  the new shit, so uh, you know, but  that's what you pay me for.  Speaking  of which, would it be possible for  me to get my twenty grand in cash?   I gotta check this with my accountant  of course, but my concern is that,  you know, it could bump me into a  higher tax--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandt, give him the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, okay, if you've already made  out the check.  Brandt is handing  him a letter-sized envelope which is  distended by something inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We received it this morning. The Dude, frowning, untucks its flap, takes out some cott wadding and unrolls it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since you have failed to achieve,  even in the modest task that was  your charge, since you have stolen  my money, and since you have  unrepentantly betrayed my trust. The wadding, undone, reveals a smaller wad of gauze taped inside.  The Dude undoes the tape with his fingernails an starts to unroll the inner package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no choice but to tell these  bums that they should do whatever is  necessary to recover their money  from you, Jeffrey Lebowski.  And  with Brandt as my witness, tell you  this:  Any further harm visited upon  Bunny, shall be visited tenfold upon  your head. Between thumb and forefinger the Dude holds up the conten of the package--a little toe, with emerald green nail pol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...By God sir.  I will not abide  another toe.

dialogues.speaker: COFFEE SHOP
dialogues.text: The Dude and Walter sit at the counter, both staring off  into space, both absently stirring their coffee with litt clinking noises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't her toe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose toe was it, Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the fuck should I know?  I do  know that nothing about it indicates--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nail polish, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, Dude.  As if it's impossible  to get some nail polish, apply it to  someone else's toe--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone else's--where the fuck are  they gonna--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a toe?  I can get you a  toe, believe me.  There are ways,  Dude.  You don't wanna know about  it, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Walter--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll  get  you  a  toe by  this  afternoon--with nail  polish. These   fucking amateurs.   They send us a   toe, we're  supposed to  shit our-  selves with fear.  Jesus Christ. My   point is--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're gonna kill her, Walter, and  then they're gonna kill me--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's just, that's the stress  talking, Dude.  So far we have what  looks to me like a series of  victimless crimes--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the toe?

dialogues.speaker: FORGET ABOUT THE FUCKING TOE
dialogues.text: A waitress enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you please keep your voices  down--this is a family restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please dear!  I've got news for  you: the Supreme Court has roundly  rejected prior restraint!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, this isn't a First Amendment  thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, if you don't calm down I'm going  to have to ask you to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady, I got buddies who died face- down in the muck so you and I could  enjoy this family restaurant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'm leaving.  I'm sorry  ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't run away from this, Dude!   Goddamnit, this affects all of us! The Dude has left frame; Walter calls after him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our basic freedoms! He looks defiantly around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm staying.  Finishing my coffee. He stirs the coffee, bopping his head in time to the Muza affecting nonchalance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finishing my coffee.

dialogues.speaker: DUDE'S BATHROOM
dialogues.text: A dripping noise. The Dude sits in the bathtub, staring stuporously, a join pinched in one hand, a washcloth draped over his head. We hear the phone ringing in the other roam. The Dude is staring at his toes, which protrude from the  soapy water, splayed against the far side of the tub. After the Dude's outgoing message we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Lebowski, this is Duty Officer  Rolvaag of the L.A.P.D. The Dude looks stuporously up, his head swaying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've recovered your vehicle.  It  can be claimed at the North Hollywood  Auto Circus there on Victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Far out.  Far fuckin' out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll just need to present a-- The message is interrupted by loud smashing sounds, as of someone applying a baseball bat to the answering machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunh? He looks blearily at the open doorway. A tall man dressed in black leather with a cricket paddle striding across the living room towards the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  This is a private residence,  man! The man has entered the bathroom and, in stride, swings t cricket paddle up to smash the overhead light.  Two other men are entering behind him. The room is dark now except for spill from the living roo the men are backlit shapes. One of them holds a string at the other end of which a sm animal skitters excitedly about the floor. The Dude looks curiously at the small, nattering animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice marmot. The man with the string scoops up the marmot and tosses i screaming, into the bathtub. The Dude screams. The marmot splashes frantically, biting at the Dude in a  frenzy of fearful aggression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vee vant zat money, Lebowski. The Dude, screaming, grabs the lip of the tub and starts hoist himself up but the first man lays a palm on top of head and squishes him back into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think veer kidding und making  mit de funny stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vee could do things you only dreamed  of, Lebowski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja, vee could really do it, Lebowski.   Vee belief in nossing. He scoops the marmot out of the water.  It shakes itself  off, spraying the Dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vee belief in nossing, Lebowski!

dialogues.speaker: NOSSING
dialogues.text: The marmot, back on the floor, is skittering around, shak itself and convulsing in little sneezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow vee come back und cut off  your chonson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: I SAY VEE CUT OFF YOUR CHONSON
dialogues.text: The three men turn to leave.  Over their retreating backs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just sink about zat, Lebowski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja, your viggly penis, Lebowski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja, und maybe vee stamp on it und  skvush it, Lebowski!

dialogues.speaker: NORTH HOLLYWOOD AUTO CIRCUS
dialogues.text: A policeman with a clipboard is leading the Dude through large parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky she wasn't chopped, Mr.   Lebowski. Must've been a joyride  situation; they abandoned the car  once they hit the retaining wall. They have reached the Dude's car.  The  driver's side   exterior has been scraped raw.  The policeman hands the D a door  handle and an exterior rear-view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These were on the road next to the  car.  You'll have to get in on the  other side. The Dude climbs in the passenger side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fucking briefcase!  It's not here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sorry, I saw that on the report.   You're lucky they left the tape deck  though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fucking briefcase!  Jesus--what's  that smell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah.  Probably a vagrant, slept  in the car.  Or perhaps just used it  as a toilet, and moved on. The Dude tries to roll down the driver's window but it wi not go; he bellows through the glass:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When will you find these guys?  I  mean, do you have any promising leads? The policeman laughs, agreeing broadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leads, yeah.  I'll just check with  the boys down at the Crime Lab.   They've assigned four more detectives  to the case, got us working in shifts. The Dude looks sadly through his window at the policeman  rocking back on his heels, his raucous laughter muffled b the glass.

dialogues.speaker: BOWLING ALLEY BAR
dialogues.text: The Dude, Walter and Donny sit at the bar, the Dude with White Russian, Walter with a beer, and Donny eating beer  nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then they're gonna stamp on it?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh for Christ--will you shut the  fuck up, Donny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure my only hope is that the  big Lebowski kills me before the  Germans can cut my dick off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that is ridiculous, Dude.  No  one is going to cut your dick off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if I have anything to say about  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks Walter.  That gives me  a very secure feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dude--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes me feel all warm inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Dude--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This whole fucking thing--I  could  be sitting here with just pee-stains  on my rug. Walter sadly shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking Germans.  Nothing changes.   Fucking Nazis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were Nazis, Dude?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Donny, they were threatening  castration!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you gonna split hairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're nihilists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kept saying they believe in  nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nihilists!  Jesus. Walter looks haunted. Say what you like about the tenets of National Socialism, Dude, at least it's an ethos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And let's also not forget--let's not  forget, Dude--that keeping wildlife,  an amphibious rodent, for uh,  domestic, you know, within the city-- that isn't legal either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you, a fucking park ranger  now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who gives a shit about the fucking  marmot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --We're sympathizing here, Dude--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck your sympathy!  I don't need  your sympathy, man, I need my fucking  Johnson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you need that for, Dude?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta buck up, man, you can't go  into the tournament with this negative  attitude--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck the tournament!  Fuck you,  Walter! There is a moment of stunned silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck the tournament?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay Dude.  I can see you don't want  to be cheered up.  C'mon Donny, let's  go get a lane. They leave the Dude sitting morosely at the bar.  As he s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another Caucasian, Gary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, Dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends like these, huh Gary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Dude. The pop song on the jukebox has ended; someone puts on  "Tumbling Tumbleweeds." A man saunters up to the bar to take the stool that Walte vacated.  He is middle-aged, amiable, craggily handsome-- Elliot, perhaps.  He has a large Western-style mustache a wears denims, a yoked shirt and a cowboy hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'ya have a good sarsaparilla? We recognize the voice of The Stranger whose narration op the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sioux City Sarsaparilla. The Stranger nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good one. Waiting for his drink, he looks amiably around the bar. crinkled eyes settle on the Dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya doin' there, Dude? The Dude, still staring down at his drink, shakes his hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh, not so good, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One a those days, huh.  Wal, a wiser  fella than m'self once said, sometimes  you eat the bar and sometimes the  bar, wal, he eats you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (absently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.  That some kind of Eastern  thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Far from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm. The bartender puts a brown bottle and a frosted glass on bar in front of The Stranger, who touches his hat brim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much obliged. He looks back at the Dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like your style, Dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I like your style too, man.   Got a whole cowboy thing goin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thankie. . . Just one thing, Dude.   D'ya have to use s'many cuss words? The Dude looks at The Stranger as if just now noticing ho out of place the cowpoke is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fuck are you talking about? The Stranger chuckles indulgently and pushes off from the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, have it your way. He brushes his hat brim with a fingertip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Thanks man. He is gone.  "Tumbling Tumbleweeds" is ending as we hear offscreen voice, breaking the spell:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dude!  Dude!

dialogues.speaker: THE DUDE LOOKS
dialogues.text: Tony, the unformed limo driver, is at the door of the bar beckoning.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE'S LOFT
dialogues.text: She strides toward us, naked under a robe which she is ju cinching shut.  Paint flecks her skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeffrey, you haven't gone to the  doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it's fine, really, uh--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any news regarding my  father's money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, uh... money, yeah, I gotta  respecfully, 69 you know, tender my  resignation on that matter, 'cause  it looks like your mother really was  kidnapped after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She most certainly was not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey man, why don't you fucking listen  occasionally?  You might learn  something.  Now I got--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And please don't call her my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I got--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is most definitely the perpetrator  and not the victim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, I got definitive  evidence--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The main guy, Dieter--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dieter Hauff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--yeah, I guess--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her "co-star" in the beaver picture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaver?  You mean vagina?--I mean,  you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dieter has been on the fringes of-- well, of everything in L.A., for  about twenty years.  Look at my LP's.   Under 'Autobahn.' The Dude fingers through the albums filling one bookshelf

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was his group--they released  one album in the mid-seventies. The Dude stops between two albums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy Orbison. . . Pink Floyd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?  Autobahn.  A-u-t-o.  Their  music is a sort of--ugh--techno-pop. The Dude pulls out an album with a worn sleeve.  On it is the group's name, Autobahn, the album name, Nagelbett, an picture

dialogues.speaker: SLICKED-
dialogues.text: back hair, gazing upward in thin-lipped epiphany.  They a wearing severe but modishly retro suits.  Each has his na under his picture--Dieter, Kieffer; and Franz.  A bed of  nails is the only set dressing on the cyc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez.  I miss vinyl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he pretending to be the abductor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...yeah--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Jeffrey, you don't really   kidnap someone that you're acquainted  with.  You can't get away with it if  the hostage knows who you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well yeah...I know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Dieter has the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no, not exactly.  It's a  complicated case, Maude.  Lotta ins.   Lotta outs.  And a lotta strands to  keep in my head, man.  Lotta strands  in old Duder's--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you still have that doctor's  number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?  No, really, I don't even have  the bruise any more, I-- She is scribbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please Jeffrey.  I don't want to be  responsible for any delayed after- effects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

In the center of the alley stands Maude Lebowski, singing operatic harmony to the Kenny Rogers song.  She wears an  armored breastplate and Norse headgear, has braided pigta and holds a trident. The Dude stands behind her and, pressed up against her, h her with her follow-through as she releases a bowling bal The lane is straddled by a line of chorines in spangly mi skirts, their arms akimbo, Busby-Berkley style, their leg turning the lane into a tunnel leading to the pins at the end. But it is no longer a bowling ball rolling between their  legs--it is the Dude himself, levitating inches off the l the tools from his utility belt swinging free.  He is fac down, his arms, torpedolike, pressed against his sides. His point of view shows the lane rushing by below, the li ball-guide arrows zipping by. The Dude twists his body around, performing a barrel-roll that he is now gliding along the lane face-up. Now his point of view looks up the dresses of the passing chorines. The Dude smiles dreamily and does a backstroke motion so  that he is once again gliding face-down.  He looks forwar and his forward momentum blows back his hair. Coming at us, as we go through the last few pairs of legs are the approaching pins.  We hit the pins, scattering th and rush on into black. A body drops down into the blackness in slow motion--a to woman, squealing, her legs kicking. As she drops out of frame, leaving blackness again, three men are entering from the background, emerging into a poo of light.  It is the Germans, advancing ominously, wieldi oversized shears which they menacingly scissor. The Dude, now standing in a field of black, reacts to the advancing Germans.  He turns and runs, fists pumping. The scissoring sound of the shears turns into the whoosh car-bys.  The field of black is punctured by headlights. dialogues.text: Huh.  Jeez.  Well, so, did he--is  that yoga? Throughout, Maude has been lying on her back with her kne pulled in.

dialogues.speaker: THE DUDE
dialogues.text: As he gets to the car.  He reaches through the open drive window and grabs the newspaper and hurls it to the ground He is revved with nervous energy.

dialogues.text: Get out of that fucking car, man! The man nervously complies.  The Dude flinches at the man movement as he gets out. The man cringes, reacting to the Dude's flinch. He is wearing a cheap blue serge suit.  He is bald with a short fringe and a mustache. The Dude shouts to cover his fear:

dialogues.text: The?  Who the fff--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus fucking Christ.

dialogues.text: Boy.  How ya gonna keep 'em down on  the farm once they seen Karl Hungus. He hands back the picture. She's been kidnapped, Da Fino.  Or maybe not, but she's  definitely not around.

dialogues.text: Four people sit at a booth:  Dieter, Kieffer, Franz, all black leather, and a young woman with long stringy blonde hair, wearing torn and patched jeans and a ribbed sleevel tee-shirt, worn thin with age.  She is apparently braless and is teutonically pale with birthmarks on her face and  arms. Notable  is  her  camera-side  leg,  which  ends in  a ba swaddled foot.  Dried rust-colored blood stains the tip o the bandage. The  four  are  arguing,  loudly,  in  Germa They seem  very unhappy. A waitress enters with a checkpa and pen.

He no  longer digs her!  It's all a show!   But then, why didn't he give a shit  about his million bucks?  I mean, he  knew we didn't hand off his briefcase,  but he never asked for it back.

Heavy metal music fil in from a boom box by the pool. Brandt, approaching, stoops and straightens, stoops and  straightens, picking up the discarded clothes that run th length of the hall.

I would've fucked  you in the ass Saturday, I'll fuck  you in the ass next Wednesday instead!

dialogues.text: Dieter, Kieffer and Franz, in shiny black leather, stand a line facing them in the all-but-deserted lot.  Behind t orange flames lick gently at the Dude's car, which has be put to the torch.  The orange flames glow on the men's  creaking leather.  Next to the car are three motorcycles, parked in a neat row.  The Dude looks sadly at the burnin car.

dialogues.text: (tremulously)

dialogues.text: (grimly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come and get it.  Fucking nihilist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me what you got.  Nihilist.   Dipshit with a nine-toed woman. In a rage, Dieter charges.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: hurls his leather satchel.

dialogues.speaker: KIEFFER
dialogues.text: Watching Dieter's charge, is caught off-guard.  The bowli ball thuds into his chest and lifts him off his feet. He falls back, his uzi clattering away.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: twists away as Dieter reaches him; grabs Dieter's head in both hands; draws Dieter's head up to his mouth, which cl on Dieter's ear.

dialogues.speaker: DUDE
dialogues.text: He rushes Franz but draws up short as Franz sends out kar kicks, his leather pants squeaking and popping.  Franz gi a loud cry with each kick; the Dude leans back, throwing arms up, evading the kicks.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: His jaw is still clamped on Dieter's ear.  Dieter draws h saber against Walter's side, drawing blood. Walter doesn't react to the wound.  Growling as Dieter  screams, he worries his ear, waggling his head with his j clamped.

dialogues.speaker: THE SABER
dialogues.text: Dieter drops it.

dialogues.speaker: DUDE
dialogues.text: Awkwardly circling, evading Franz's kicks.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: still worrying the ear.  With a tearing sound his head an Dieter's separate.

dialogues.speaker: BELIEF IN NUSSING
dialogues.text: Walter spits his ear into his face.

dialogues.speaker: DUDE
dialogues.text: The Dude and Franz, both now panting heavily, have yet to establish body contact.  Franz continues to kick.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: draws back his fist.

dialogues.speaker: ANTI-SEMITE
dialogues.text: Bam!--A powerhouse blow to the middle of his face drops D for the count.

dialogues.speaker: DUDE AND FRANZ
dialogues.text: With a piercing shriek Franz finally summons the nerve to charge the Dude, hands raised to deliver karate blows. As he reaches the Dude--WHHAP--the  boom box swings into frame to smash him in the face.  Its volume shoots up. Walter bashes him a few more times over the head.  The mu screeches to static, then quiet.  Laid out now, Franz too quiet. All quiet. Walter, panting, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got a man down, Dude. With a hand pressed to his bleeding side he trots over to Donny, who lies gasping on the ground. The Dude, also panting, rises and trots over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hy God!  They shot him, Walter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shot Donny! Donny gasps for air.  His eyes, wide, go from the Dude to Walter.  One hand still clutches his eighteen dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There weren't any shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the medics, Dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha. . . Donny--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry Dude.  I'd go but I'm pumping  blood.  Might pass out. The Dude runs into the lanes.  Walter lays a reassuring h on Donny's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rest easy, good buddy, you're doing  fine.  We got help choppering in.

They sit side by side, forearms on knees, in a nondescrip waiting area.  Walter bounces the fingertips of one hand those of the other.  They sit.  They wait. A tall thin man in a conservative black suit enters.  He  eyes the Dude's bowling attire and sunglasses and Walter' army surplus, but doesn't make an issue of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, gentlemen.  You are the  bereaved?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis Donnelly.  Pleased to meet  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeffrey Lebowski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter Sobchak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dude, actually.  Is what, uh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I understand you're taking  away the remains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have the urn. He nods through a door.  Another man in a black suit ente to carefully deposit a large silver urn on the desktop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I assume this is credit card? He is vaguely handing a large leather folder across the d to whomever wants to take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He takes it, opens it, puts on reading glasses that sit  halfway down his nose, and inspects the bill with his hea pulled back for focus and cocked for concentration.  Sile The Dude smiles at Donnelly.  Donnelly gives back a  mortician's smile.  At length Walter holds the bill towar Donnelly, pointing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is for the urn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't need it.  We're scattering the  ashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, so we were informed.  However,  we must of course transmit the remains  to you in a receptacle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a hundred and eighty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.  It is our most modestly  priced receptacle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well can we--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred and eighty dollars?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They range up to three thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but we're--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we just rent it from you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, this is a mortuary, not a rental  house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're scattering the fucking ashes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, please lower your voice--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey man, don't you have something  else you could put it in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is our most modestly priced  receptacle.

dialogues.speaker: POINT DUME
dialogues.text: It is a high, wind-swept bluff.  Walter and the Dude walk towards the lip of the bluff.  Parked in the background i one lonely car, Walter's. Walter is carrying a bright red coffee can with a blue pl lid.  When they reach the edge the two men stand awkwardl for a beat.  Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say a few words. The Dude clasps his hands in front of him.  Walter clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donny was a good bowler, and a good  man.  He was. . . He was one of us.   He was a man who loved the outdoors,  and bowling, and as a surfer explored  the beaches of southern California  from Redondo to Calabassos.  And he  was an avid bowler.  And a good  friend.  He died--he died as so many  of his generation, before his time.   In your wisdom you took him, Lord.   As you took so many bright flowering  young men, at Khe San and Lan Doc  and Hill 364.  These young men gave  their lives.  And Donny too.  Donny  who. . . who loved bowling. Walter clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so, Theodore--Donald--Karabotsos,  in accordance with what we think    your dying wishes might well have  been, we commit your mortal remains  to the bosom of. Walter is peeling the plastic lid off the coffee can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the Pacific Ocean, which you loved  so well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, sweet prince. The wind has blown all of the ashes into the Dude, standi just to the side of and behind Walter. The Dude stands,  frozen. Finished eulogizing, Walter looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, I'm sorry Dude. He starts brushing off the Dude with his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn wind. Heretofore motionless, the Dude finally explodes, slappin Walter's hands away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamnit Walter!  You fucking  asshole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dude!  Dude, I'm sorry! The Dude is near tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make everything a fucking  travesty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dude, I'm--it was an accident! The Dude gives Walter a furious shove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about that shit about Vietnam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dude, I'm sorry--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck does Vietnam have to  do with anything!  What the fuck  were you talking about?! Walter for the first time is genuinely distressed, almost lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit Dude, I'm sorry--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a fuck, Walter! He gives Walter a weaker shove.  Walter seems dazed, then wraps his arms around the Dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awww, fuck it Dude.  Let's go bowling.

dialogues.speaker: THE LANES THE DUDE AND WALTER BOWLING
dialogues.text: We watch each of them glide across the floor, release, fo through--gracefully.  We have never seen them bowl before They are quite good.  Each wears a black armband on his  bowling shirt.

dialogues.speaker: BAR AREA
dialogues.text: The Dude walks up to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two oat sodas, Gary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  Good luck tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to hear about Donny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Well, you know, sometimes you  eat the bear, and, uh. "Tumbling Tumbleweeds" has come up on the jukebox, and Th Stranger ambles up to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy do, Dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hey man, how are ya?  I wondered  if I'd see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't miss the semis.  How things  been goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh, you know.  Strikes and gutters,  ups and downs. The Stranger's eyes crinkle merrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I gotcha. The bartender has put two gleaming beers on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Gary...Take care, man, I  gotta get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  Take it easy, Dude--I know  that you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah man.  Well, you know, the Dude  abides. Gazing after him, The Stranger drawls, savoring the words

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dude abides. He gives his head a shake of appreciation, then looks int the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about you, but I take  comfort in that.  It's good knowin'  he's out there, the Dude, takin' her  easy for all us sinners.  Shoosh.  I  sure hope he makes The finals.  Welp,  that about does her, wraps her all  up.  Things seem to've worked out  pretty good for the Dude'n Walter,  and it was a purt good story, dontcha  think?   Made me laugh to beat the  band.  Parts, anyway.  Course--I  didn't like seein' Donny go. But  then, happen to know that there's a  little Lebowski on the way.  I guess  that's the way the whole durned human  comedy keeps perpetuatin' it-self,  down through the generations, westward  the wagons, across the sands a time  until-- aw, look at me, I'm ramblin'  again.  Wal, uh hope you folks enjoyed  yourselves. He brushes his hat brim with a fingertip as we begin to p back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catch ya further on down the trail. As we pull away The Stranger swivels in to the bar.  As h voice fades:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Say friend, ya got any more a  that good sarsaparilla?...
